title: Reeves Faces The City, Nvida's China Surprise, EU Targets Boeing & Bourbon | Bloomberg Daybreak:...

rawLines.text: [Music]
Bloomberg Audio Studios podcasts, radio,
news.
This is the Bloomberg Daybreak Europe
podcast. Good morning. It's Tuesday the
15th of July. I'm Caroline Hepka in
London
and I'm Steven Carol in Brussels. Coming
up today, the UK's Chancellor Rachel
Reeves will face the city for her first
major speech since her tearful
appearance in parliament sparked a bond
market selloff. Nvidia gets the green
light to resume certain AI chip sales to
China after a dramatic White House
reversal.
Plus, targeting Boeing and Bourbon, the
EU finalizes a new tariff retaliation
list hitting American goods worth $84
billion if a trade deal can't be
reached.
Let's start with a roundup of our top
stories. Britain's Chancellor Rachel
Reeves will pledge to cut red tape in
her annual speech to London's financial
sector in a bid to help drive the
government's growth plans. Reeves is
expected to say that dialing up risk
will allow more families access to
mortgages. It'll be the chancellor's
first major public speech since UK
assets sold off less than two weeks ago
when she appeared visibly upset in
Parliament. But since then, the city has
grown increasingly wary of taxes down
the line. Bloomberg's James Wilark has
the story.
Chancellor Reeves's mansion house dinner
could be mistaken for tapass. There are
many small plates on offer to the
financial sector, a concier service for
international investors, reforms to the
financial ombbudsman, and a new captive
insurance regime. And the city has been
teased with hopes for a review of ring
fencing rules and possibly an
entrepreneurs visa system. But despite
these tasty morsels around deregulation
and growth, many in the world of finance
see the government's fiscal worries. I
wonder if the bill is going to be coming
later in the autumn budget. In London,
James Walco, Bloomberg Radio.
Well, the chancellor's speech comes as
the UK economy shows more signs of
rebounding from its recent slump. June's
retail sales figures rose by 3.1% from a
year earlier, according to data from the
British Retail Consortium. It's a
positive signal after US tariffs, tax
increases, and a minimum wage hike drove
backto back contractions in retail sales
in April and May.
Nvidia is preparing to resume sales of
high-end AI chips to China after getting
the green light from the Trump
administration. The H20 chip was
designed specifically by Nvidia to
comply with earlier US trade
restrictions, but has been banned from
sale in the country since April. In a
blog in a blog post, the tech giant says
that US officials have now told them
they will approve export licenses. Gene
Monster of Deep Water Asset Management
says the move comes after weeks of
thawing relations between Beijing and
Washington.
My suspicion is that some of this
semi-trade truce, I'm reluctant given
everything that's going on to call it
that, but that we have seen between the
US and China probably laid the
groundwork a few weeks ago that this in
fact was was going to happen with
Nvidia. And so what does it mean? What
is the Trump administration essentially
saying is that they have to give
something to get something. Gene Monster
adds the US reversal is a significant
win for Nvidia CEO Jensen Hang. He had
previously branded Washington's chip
curbs a failure that fueled the rise of
Huawei and other Chinese AI rivals.
Some more data now. China's economy grew
faster than expected in the second
quarter. GDP rose by 5.2%
after a gain of 5.4% in the first three
months of the year. However, strong
exports to markets outside the US mass
deepening pressure from weak domestic
demand within China despite a raft of
government subsidies, excess
manufacturing capacity, and weak
confidence in the property sector
continue to suppress Chinese
consumption.
US President Donald Trump has threatened
to impose severe tariffs on Russia if it
does not end the war with Ukraine. The
news comes as the US pledges fresh
weapon supplies for Kev, which Trump
says will be paid for by NATO member
states. Speaking during a meeting with
NATO Secretary General at the White
House, Trump set out a timeline for the
Russian president.
I'm disappointed in President Putin
because I thought we would have had a
deal two months ago, but it doesn't seem
to get there. So based on that, we're
going to be doing secondary tariffs if
we don't have a deal in 50 days. It's
very simple and they'll be at 100%.
President Trump speaking during a
meeting with NATO's Mark Rut there. Matt
Whitaker, the US ambassador to NATO,
says the planned action effectively
represents secondary sanctions on
countries that are buying oil from
Russia. The president didn't elaborate
on the powers he would use to impose
those tariffs, but said he wasn't sure
if congressional approval would be
needed.
Bloomberg understands that the European
Union has finalized a second list of US
tariff counter measures targeting goods
worth 72 billion euros. The list
includes Boeing aircraft and bourbon as
well as additional duties on machinery
products, chemicals and plastics,
medical devices, wines and other
agricultural goods. Our senior White
House correspondent Josh Windgrove says
Europe is a significant market for
President Trump. And the question is, of
course, will they land somewhere or will
Trump look at wherever they are in a
week or two and think that that's either
not enough and stick with the 30% or it
is enough and go to a lower number.
Remember, of course, the baseline number
right now is 10%, he initially announced
20% on Europe in those uh initial
liberation day tariffs. He's threatened
as high as 50% on Europe. And he's
always, you know, that's been kind of
the one of the top of the list places
that he's complained about when he talks
about unfair trade relationships.
Bloomberg's Josh Windgrove there on
Trump's EU tariff plans. EU member
states still need to give their approval
though before the European list is
adopted. The measures are a response to
President Trump's earlier so-called
reciprocal tariff of 20% hitting most
goods and the additional levies on cars
and car parts of 25%. The universal rate
was later temporarily lowered to 10% to
allow negotiations to take place.
France's prime minister will outline a
plan today to sharply narrow the
country's budget deficit. The move by
Franceu sets the stage for a
parliamentary battle at risks triggering
another government collapse. Prime
Minister will present details of around4
billion e in spending cuts and tax
increases for next year. The proposals
are aimed at shrinking the euro area's
largest budget gap as France's fiscal
difficulties continue to rattle bond
markets. Earlier this month, the
country's 5-year bond yield surpassed
Italy's for the first time in 20 years.
And those are our top stories for you
this morning. So, let's think about
markets which are really focused on the
US inflation data. There are a number of
other countries reporting CPI, but the
US is the most significant coming out at
1:30 p.m. Clues on the impact of Trump
tariffs uh in June uh and the direction
of course of interest rates. In terms of
the market response at the moment, the
MCEI Asia Pacific index has been
swinging between small gains and losses.
So, a lot of hesitation. Japan's 10-year
government bond yields are climbing to
its highest level since 2008. You've
also got corporate earnings season
though really taking hold. JP Morgan
Chase, Wells Fargo City, and Black
Rockck all due to report today. Subdued
expectations. So, do we see some big
beats there? And Bitcoin, we saw a surge
on Monday. We are below that 117,000
this morning. So, a pretty incredible
run though for uh Bitcoin over the
course of this year, something like uh
27%. Those are the markets.
In a moment, we'll look ahead to
tonight's Mansion House speech from the
Chancellor. I'm bringing you the latest
on the EU US trade dispute with another
story we've been reading this morning.
Now, Caroline, it's been a long time
since I owned a car. But every time I
rent one, I am sort of mystified by the
block of plastic that I get handed at
the counter because keys are out, fobs
are in. Everyone else knows this except
me like you who drives regularly. Uh but
apparently this is something that now
has become a a key design feature of
high-end cars as well.
I love how this is described in Hannah
Elliot's piece. It's like the handshake.
You know, it gives you a little um taste
of what the car design is all about. you
know, get it wrong and you can be
severely punished by um by drivers, as
you say. Yes. I I think of you, Stephen,
as the ultimate car-free European city
dweller.
Belgians love cars. So, you know, maybe
maybe things will change now that I'm in
Brussels. You know, maybe I'll be
finally tempted back onto the roads. But
I like some of the designs in this piece
of the the kind of the fancy fobs are
are incredible. Like there's a there's a
Bentley one there. There's the Lotus
Pebble, which is sort of a triangle. You
know, there's a lot of effort now being
put into designing what these things
look like. They're meant to be a
reflection of the vehicle. They don't
always get it right. Hannah Elliot
points it out points out as well that
there was a recent Cadillac model that
kind of didn't go down very well because
it was essentially just a plastic piece
in a little leather wallet. People
didn't feel reflected the luxury of the
car
and that probably the price tag as well.
I mean, look, even the key fob though
might be going extinct because actually
loads of the high-end cars just have
apps now.
Open it with your mind, Caroline. That's
to be the next step. I think you can
read Hannah's piece on blueber.com and
on the terminal. We'll put a link to the
article in our show notes as well. But
the Chancellor Rachel Reeves makes her
annual speech to London's financial
industry later at Mansion House. A key
moment for the sector, but also for the
chancellor for herself after the recent
market jitters over her future. Our
finance reporter Leo Ken Sheper joins us
now for more. Leo, good morning. What
are the key announcements then we're
expecting from the chancellor?
Good morning, Stephen. Uh yes. So ahead
of uh Rachel Reef's annual mention house
speech in the city, the chancellor will
actually be in leads first first off and
reveal measures to increase home
ownership. And she you know she will
reveal I think you said earlier as well
a permanent mortgage guarantee scheme
and also more home loans for people on
lower incomes. And then when she's in
the city tonight, she is going to
announce a among various other things a
concierge service for international
investors who want to put uh money into
the UK and that service will sort of
help them navigate issues around visas
and regulation. Another key measure
that's uh hotly anticipated by many in
the city is uh cutting the burden of the
senior managers and certification
regime. um basically making it easier
for financial institutions to appoint
senior managers and shortening the the
regulatory review from three to two
months. Those are some of the measures
that are expected tonight.
Yeah. Okay. So, what are we expecting
then and might we get any announcements
on tax? Because that's the other big
worry.
Yes, exactly. That's the big one. Um so
our understanding is to not expect any
announcements on tax but any signaling
around wealth taxes non-dom taxes
potential backtracking here uh would
most likely be the biggest uh story out
of the the mention house speech. You
know, when I was talking to people in
the city, asking them what they expect
uh tonight, they they would always ask
ask the question back, you know, well,
what are you hearing about wealth taxes?
You know, that's definitely a big thorn
in the side uh for many people in the
city. The Lord Mayor, Alistister King,
who is hosting the dinner tonight, uh
told us a few weeks ago that the
government really needs to stop the
Nondom exodus and many expect the
Treasury to act eventually, but probably
not today.
How significant is this moment for
Rachel Reeves after we had that recent
guilt market selloff?
Yeah, it's a it's a good question. So,
um it definitely is a big moment for
her. I'd say not necessarily for the
guild market because there are no fiscal
measures expected. Um I was talking to
guild market participants and they're
not necessarily waiting with baited
breath for what Ree is going to say. But
I think it's key for her to maintain her
support from from people in the city um
from executives. She was off to a good
start, you know, praised by CEOs of
asset managers for instance for for her
growth agenda. But uh the NOM exodus and
also relatively slow movement around
issues such as the reform of of ISAS,
the individual savings accounts that has
definitely irritated some of her early
supporters in the city.
Interesting. Yeah. So Rachel Ree
speaking tonight at the Mansion House
dinner, but also the Bank of England
Governor Andrew Bailey will be
delivering his annual speech at that
event too. Leo, thank you so much for
looking ahead to what's happening today.
Our finance reporter Leo Ken Sherper.
Now
the European Union has finalized a
second list of counter measures
targeting American goods worth 72
billion euros if it decides to retaliate
as transatlantic trade tensions
intensified. The EU is still hopeful it
can negotiate a deal to avoid the 30%
levy threatened by Donald Trump. Let's
bring in our EMA news director Rosa Mat
for more on this as well. First, Ross,
just on what we've been hearing from
Donald Trump, he's indicated he's open
to more talks with the EU, but is there
any sign of actually any progress?
Well, it does make it a bit harder when
Donald Trump says that his letters
laying out tariff rates are actual deals
because they're not. It's the US
imposing a tariff rate. So that's the
climate in which a lot of countries are
trying to negotiate or work out how to
negotiate with the US and the path
forward. There's been lots of rounds of
talks between the EU and the US. There
are more to come. Uh the EU EU trade
negotiator uh Maroskovich was due to
talk last night uh with the US commerce
secretary Howard Lutnik. So we'll see
how that went. He's also warned that
while they have to prepare for all
outcomes that this proposed duty he said
is quote effectively prohibitive for
transatlantic trade. Um the preference
is still for a deal. I mean there's
wrangling between the EU some of the
biggest states are saying should we do a
deal for the sake of it? Should we
insist it has to be a good one no matter
what? But the general feeling is they
want a deal. They want to avoid tipping
into an even bigger trade conflict. And
that's very much also the view that
they're getting from business in the EU.
Yeah. Let's see, of course, how long
maybe that lasts because the EU has been
very careful not to antagonize President
Trump with retaliation so far. But um
let's see if that is a strategy that
continues or not. I also want a quick
word though on what is going on with
Russia. The US president has threatened
big tariffs on Russia up to 100% if it
doesn't end hostilities with Ukraine.
Now, will that tactic work with Vladimir
Putin, Ros?
Well, that is the question. Obviously,
it's a signal of just how frustrated
Donald Trump is that there's no movement
towards a ceasefire in Ukraine and now
very much training his sights on Putin
in all of that. But the Russian economy
is already very heavily sanctioned,
including by the US. It seems like it
was a bit unclear what Donald Trump was
saying last night, but it suggests that
he's talking about perhaps further
tariffs on Russia goods and Russia
doesn't export a lot to the US, but
primarily talking about secondary
sanctions, which would penalize
countries like China and India for
buying Russian energy, of course, that
they've bought quite a lot in recent
years, and that's helped fund the war in
Ukraine. And that would be a designed to
squeeze the Russian economy further.
You'd have to say that with all this
pressure that's gone on and Donald Trump
saying that he's talking with Vladimir
Putin all the time and Vladimir Putin
wants a deal, there's no great sign that
Vladimir Putin wants a deal on Ukraine,
that he want he doesn't want to keep
pressing on with his war aims there
regardless. And that's despite many
years of economic squeeze. Um would this
change his course in Ukraine? It's very
hard to say. Would it hurt the Russian
economy further? Absolutely. But
Vladimir Putin seems to be quite willing
to wear a lot of economic pain uh to
further his goals in Ukraine.
This is Bloomberg Daybreak Europe, your
morning brief on the stories making news
from London to Wall Street and beyond.
Look for us on your podcast feed every
morning on Apple, Spotify, and anywhere
else you get your podcasts.
You can also listen live each morning on
London DAB radio, the Bloomberg Business
App, and Bloomberg.com. Our flagship New
York station is also available on your
Amazon Alexa devices. Just say, "Alexa,
play Bloomberg 11:30." I'm Caroline
Hepka.
And I'm Steven Carroll. Join us again
tomorrow morning for all the news you
need to start your day right here on
Bloomberg Daybreak Europe.
[Music]

cleanText:
[Music]
Bloomberg Audio Studios podcasts, radio, news.
This is the *Bloomberg Daybreak Europe* podcast.
Good morning.
It's Tuesday, the 15th of July.
I'm Caroline Hepka in London, and I'm Steven Carol in Brussels.
Coming up today, the UK's Chancellor, Rachel Reeves, will face the City for her first major speech since her tearful appearance in Parliament sparked a bond market selloff.
Nvidia gets the green light to resume certain AI chip sales to China after a dramatic White House reversal.
Plus, targeting Boeing and Bourbon, the EU finalizes a new tariff retaliation list hitting American goods worth $84 billion if a trade deal can't be reached.
Let's start with a roundup of our top stories.
Britain's Chancellor, Rachel Reeves, will pledge to cut red tape in her annual speech to London's financial sector in a bid to help drive the government's growth plans.
Reeves is expected to say that dialing up risk will allow more families access to mortgages.
It'll be the chancellor's first major public speech since UK assets sold off less than two weeks ago when she appeared visibly upset in Parliament.
But since then, the City has grown increasingly wary of taxes down the line.
Bloomberg's James Wilark has the story.
Chancellor Reeves's mansion house dinner could be mistaken for tapass.
There are many small plates on offer to the financial sector, a concierge service for international investors, reforms to the financial ombudsman, and a new captive insurance regime.
And the City has been teased with hopes for a review of ring-fencing rules and possibly an entrepreneurs visa system.
But despite these tasty morsels around deregulation and growth, many in the world of finance see the government's fiscal worries.
I wonder if the bill is going to be coming later in the autumn budget.
In London, James Walco, Bloomberg Radio.
Well, the chancellor's speech comes as the UK economy shows more signs of rebounding from its recent slump.
June's retail sales figures rose by 3.1% from a year earlier, according to data from the British Retail Consortium.
It's a positive signal after US tariffs, tax increases, and a minimum wage hike drove back-to-back contractions in retail sales in April and May.
Nvidia is preparing to resume sales of high-end AI chips to China after getting the green light from the US administration.
The H20 chip was designed specifically by Nvidia to comply with earlier US trade restrictions, but has been banned from sale in the country since April.
In a blog post, the tech giant says that US officials have now told them they will approve export licenses.
Gene Monster of Deep Water Asset Management says the move comes after weeks of thawing relations between Beijing and Washington.
My suspicion is that some of this semi-trade truce, I'm reluctant given everything that's going on to call it that, but that we have seen between the US and China probably laid the groundwork a few weeks ago that this in fact was going to happen with Nvidia.
And so what does it mean?
What is the US administration essentially saying is that they have to give something to get something.
Gene Monster adds the US reversal is a significant win for Nvidia CEO Jensen Hang.
He had previously branded Washington's chip curbs a failure that fueled the rise of Huawei and other Chinese AI rivals.
Some more data now.
China's economy grew faster than expected in the second quarter.
GDP rose by 5.2% after a gain of 5.4% in the first three months of the year.
However, strong exports to markets outside the US mass deepening pressure from weak domestic demand within China despite a raft of government subsidies, excess manufacturing capacity, and weak confidence in the property sector continue to suppress Chinese consumption.
US President Donald Trump has threatened to impose severe tariffs on Russia if it does not end the war with Ukraine.
The news comes as the US pledges fresh weapon supplies for Kyiv, which Trump says will be paid for by NATO member states.
Speaking during a meeting with NATO Secretary General at the White House, Trump set out a timeline for the Russian president.
I'm disappointed in President Putin because I thought we would have had a deal two months ago, but it doesn't seem to get there.
So based on that, we're going to be doing secondary tariffs if we don't have a deal in 50 days.
It's very simple and they'll be at 100%.
President Trump speaking during a meeting with NATO's Mark Rut there.
Matt Whitaker, the US ambassador to NATO, says the planned action effectively represents secondary sanctions on countries that are buying oil from Russia.
The president didn't elaborate on the powers he would use to impose those tariffs, but said he wasn't sure if congressional approval would be needed.
Bloomberg understands that the European Union has finalized a second list of US tariff counter measures targeting goods worth 72 billion euros.
The list includes Boeing aircraft and Bourbon as well as additional duties on machinery products, chemicals and plastics, medical devices, wines and other agricultural goods.
Our senior White House correspondent Josh Windgrove says Europe is a significant market for President Trump.
And the question is, of course, will they land somewhere or will Trump look at wherever they are in a week or two and think that that's either not enough and stick with the 30% or it is enough and go to a lower number.
Remember, of course, the baseline number right now is 10%, he initially announced 20% on Europe in those initial liberation day tariffs.
He's threatened as high as 50% on Europe.
And he's always, you know, that's been kind of the one of the top of the list places that he's complained about when he talks about unfair trade relationships.
Bloomberg's Josh Windgrove there on Trump's EU tariff plans.
EU member states still need to give their approval though before the European list is adopted.
The measures are a response to President Trump's earlier so-called reciprocal tariff of 20% hitting most goods and the additional levies on cars and car parts of 25%.
The universal rate was later temporarily lowered to 10% to allow negotiations to take place.
France's prime minister will outline a plan today to sharply narrow the country's budget deficit.
The move by France sets the stage for a parliamentary battle at risks triggering another government collapse.
Prime Minister will present details of around 4 billion euros in spending cuts and tax increases for next year.
The proposals are aimed at shrinking the euro area's largest budget gap as France's fiscal difficulties continue to rattle bond markets.
Earlier this month, the country's 5-year bond yield surpassed Italy's for the first time in 20 years.
And those are our top stories for you this morning.
So, let's think about markets which are really focused on the US inflation data.
There are a number of other countries reporting CPI, but the US is the most significant coming out at 1:30 p.m.
Clues on the impact of Trump tariffs in June and the direction of course of interest rates.
In terms of the market response at the moment, the MCEI Asia Pacific index has been swinging between small gains and losses.
So, a lot of hesitation.
Japan's 10-year government bond yields are climbing to its highest level since 2008.
You've also got corporate earnings season though really taking hold.
JP Morgan Chase, Wells Fargo City, and Black Rock all due to report today.
Subdued expectations.
So, do we see some big beats there?
And Bitcoin, we saw a surge above $120,000 on Monday.
We are below that 117,000 this morning.
So, a pretty incredible run though for Bitcoin over the course of this year, something like 27%.
Those are the markets.
In a moment, we'll look ahead to tonight's Mansion House speech from the Chancellor.
I'm bringing you the latest on the EU US trade dispute with another story we've been reading this morning.
Now, Caroline, it's been a long time since I owned a car.
But every time I rent one, I am sort of mystified by the block of plastic that I get handed at the counter because keys are out, fobs are in.
Everyone else knows this except me like you who drives regularly.
Uh but apparently this is something that now has become a key design feature of high-end cars as well.
I love how this is described in Hannah Elliot's piece.
It's like the handshake.
You know, it gives you a little taste of what the car design is all about.
You know, get it wrong and you can be severely punished by drivers, as you say.
Yes.
I I think of you, Stephen, as the ultimate car-free European city dweller.
Belgians love cars.
So, you know, maybe things will change now that I'm in Brussels.
You know, maybe I'll be finally tempted back onto the roads.
But I like some of the designs in this piece of the the kind of the fancy fobs are incredible.
Like there's a there's a Bentley one there.
There's the Lotus Pebble, which is sort of a triangle.
You know, there's a lot of effort now being put into designing what these things look like.
They're meant to be a reflection of the vehicle.
They don't always get it right.
Hannah Elliot points it out points out as well that there was a recent Cadillac model that kind of didn't go down very well because it was essentially just a plastic piece in a little leather wallet.
People didn't feel reflected the luxury of the car and that probably the price tag as well.
I mean, look, even the key fob though might be going extinct because actually loads of the high-end cars just have apps now.
Open it with your mind, Caroline.
That's to be the next step.
I think you can read Hannah's piece on blueber.com and on the terminal.
We'll put a link to the article in our show notes as well.
But the Chancellor Rachel Reeves makes her annual speech to London's financial industry later at Mansion House.
A key moment for the sector, but also for the chancellor for herself after the recent market jitters over her future.
Our finance reporter Leo Ken Sheper joins us now for more.
Leo, good morning.
What are the key announcements then we're expecting from the chancellor?
Good morning, Stephen.
Uh yes.
So ahead of Rachel Reeves's annual mention house speech in the City, the chancellor will actually be in Leeds first off and reveal measures to increase home ownership.
And she you know she will reveal I think you said earlier as well a permanent mortgage guarantee scheme and also more home loans for people on lower incomes.
And then when she's in the City tonight, she is going to announce a among various other things a concierge service for international investors who want to put money into the UK and that service will sort of help them navigate issues around visas and regulation.
Another key measure that's hotly anticipated by many in the City is cutting the burden of the senior managers and certification regime.
Um basically making it easier for financial institutions to appoint senior managers and shortening the the regulatory review from three to two months.
Those are some of the measures that are expected tonight.
Yeah.
Okay.
So, what are we expecting then and might we get any announcements on tax?
Because that's the other big worry.
Yes, exactly.
That's the big one.
Um so our understanding is to not expect any announcements on tax but any signaling around wealth taxes non-dom taxes potential backtracking here would most likely be the biggest story out of the mention house speech.
You know, when I was talking to people in the City, asking them what they expect tonight, they they would always ask ask the question back, you know, well, what are you hearing about wealth taxes?
You know, that's definitely a big thorn in the side for many people in the City.
The Lord Mayor, Alistister King, who is hosting the dinner tonight, told us a few weeks ago that the government really needs to stop the Nondom exodus and many expect the Treasury to act eventually, but probably not today.
How significant is this moment for Rachel Reeves after we had that recent guilt market selloff?
Yeah, it's a good question.
So, um it definitely is a big moment for her.
I'd say not necessarily for the guild market because there are no fiscal measures expected.
Um I was talking to guild market participants and they're not necessarily waiting with baited breath for what Ree is going to say.
But I think it's key for her to maintain her support from people in the City um from executives.
She was off to a good start, you know, praised by CEOs of asset managers for instance for for her growth agenda.
But the NOM exodus and also relatively slow movement around issues such as the reform of of ISAS, the individual savings accounts that has definitely irritated some of her early supporters in the City.
Interesting.
Yeah.
So Rachel Ree speaking tonight at the Mansion House dinner, but also the Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey will be delivering his annual speech at that event too.
Leo, thank you so much for looking ahead to what's happening today.
Our finance reporter Leo Ken Sherper.
Now the European Union has finalized a second list of counter measures targeting American goods worth 72 billion euros if it decides to retaliate as transatlantic trade tensions intensified.
The EU is still hopeful it can negotiate a deal to avoid the 30% levy threatened by Donald Trump.
Let's bring in our EMA news director Rosa Mat for more on this as well.
First, Ross, just on what we've been hearing from Donald Trump, he's indicated he's open to more talks with the EU, but is there any sign of actually any progress?
Well, it does make it a bit harder when Donald Trump says that his letters laying out tariff rates are actual deals because they're not.
It's the US imposing a tariff rate.
So that's the climate in which a lot of countries are trying to negotiate or work out how to negotiate with the US and the path forward.
There's been lots of rounds of talks between the EU and the US.
There are more to come.
Uh the EU EU trade negotiator Maroskovich was due to talk last night with the US commerce secretary Howard Lutnik.
So we'll see how that went.
He's also warned that while they have to prepare for all outcomes that this proposed duty he said is quote effectively prohibitive for transatlantic trade.
Um the preference is still for a deal.
I mean there's wrangling between the EU some of the biggest states are saying should we do a deal for the sake of it?
Should we insist it has to be a good one no matter what?
But the general feeling is they want a deal.
They want to avoid tipping into an even bigger trade conflict.
And that's very much also the view that they're getting from business in the EU.
Yeah.
Let's see, of course, how long maybe that lasts because the EU has been very careful not to antagonize President Trump with retaliation so far.

Vladimir Putin, Ros?

Well, that is the question. And that would be a designed to squeeze the Russian economy further. You'd have to say that with all this pressure that's gone on and Donald Trump saying that he's talking with Vladimir Putin all the time and Vladimir Putin wants a deal, there's no great sign that Vladimir Putin wants a deal on Ukraine, that he doesn't want to keep pressing on with his war aims there regardless. And that's despite many years of economic squeeze. Would this change his course in Ukraine? It's very hard to say. Would it hurt the Russian economy further? Absolutely.
